metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (Cosmic-ray observation system of soil moisture of Daman Superstation, 2019)
metadata.description:
This dataset includes data recorded by the Heihe integrated observatory network obtained from a Cosmic-ray Soil Moisture Observing System of soil moisture of Daman Superstation from January 1 to December 31, 2019. The site (100.372° E, 38.856° N) was located on a cropland (maize surface) in the Daman irrigation, which is near Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The elevation is 1556 m. The bottom of the probe was 0.5 m above the ground; the sampling interval was 1 hour.
The raw COSMOS data include the following: battery (Batt, V), temperature (T, C), relative humidity (RH, %), air pressure (P, hPa), fast neutron counts (N1C, counts per hour), thermal neutron counts (N2C, counts per hour), sample time of fast neutrons (N1ET, s), and sample time of thermal neutrons (N2ET, s). The distributed data include the following variables: Date, Time, P, N1C, N1C_cor (corrected fast neutron counts) and VWC (volume soil moisture, %), which were processed as follows:
1) Data were removed and replaced by -6999 when (a) the battery voltage was less than 11.8 V, (b) the relative humidity was greater than 80% inside the probe box, (c) the counting data were not of one-hour duration and (d) neutron count differed from the previous value by more than 20%; 2) An air pressure correction was applied to the quality-controlled raw data according to the equation contained in the equipment manual; 3) After the quality control and corrections were applied, soil moisture was calculated using the equation in Zreda et al. (2012), where N0 is the neutron counts above dry soil and the other variables are fitted constants that define the shape of the calibration function. Here, the parameter N0 was calibrated using the in situ observed soil moisture by SoilNET within the footprint; 4) Based on the calibrated N0 and corrected N1C, the hourly soil moisture was computed using the equation from the equipment manual. Moreover, suspicious data were marked in red.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Zhu et al. (2015) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

background: The acquisition of regional surface soil moisture has long been a research challenge. In recent years, the study of measuring regional surface soil moisture using cosmic ray fast neutron methods has made significant progress. As a novel medium-scale non-destructive measurement method for soil moisture, the cosmic ray fast neutron method can obtain soil moisture within a source area of approximately 300 meters in radius. This larger measurement area fills the gap between traditional point observations and remote sensing large-area observations. Traditional measurement methods include: gravimetric method (oven-drying method), neutron gauge method, capacitance method, tensiometer method, time-domain reflectometry (TDR), and frequency-domain reflectometry (FDR). These measurement methods are all destructive and point-based, with measurement scales mostly at small scales, poor spatial representativeness, and difficulty in obtaining information on the regional distribution of soil moisture. The feasibility study of remote sensing monitoring of soil moisture began in the 1960s, with applied research starting in the mid-1970s. Remote sensing technology can achieve rapid and large-area monitoring of soil moisture, but the soil moisture obtained through remote sensing is an average value at the pixel scale, with spatial resolutions generally ranging from tens of meters (aerial remote sensing) to tens of kilometers (satellite remote sensing), and it only provides instantaneous values at the time of aircraft or satellite overpass, limiting the application of large-scale remote sensing measurements in practical soil moisture monitoring. There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing monitoring, which is the inability to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, it is not possible to obtain the required pixel-scale soil moisture data during the validation of remotely sensed soil moisture retrievals. In recent years, the research on measuring surface soil moisture using cosmic ray fast neutrons has gradually attracted attention. The intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons above the surface is inversely related to soil moisture content. By setting up a neutron probe above the surface to measure the intensity of cosmic ray fast neutrons, the surface soil moisture content can be inferred. The cosmic ray fast neutron method is a passive, non-invasive medium-scale soil moisture measurement method, with a measurement radius of about 300 meters and an effective measurement depth of 12 to 76 cm.
research objective: This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye region in the middle reaches of the Heihe River, and compares the results with data from Wireless Sensor Networks (WSN) to analyze the reliability of cosmic ray observations. The article analyzes the experimental results of regional soil moisture observations conducted in the Zhangye oasis farmland, indicating that the cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content. It not only accurately captures long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also provides meaningful ground validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture.
challenges: There is a gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale monitoring through remote sensing, which makes it difficult to obtain regional soil moisture information at the scale of farmland or small watersheds. Similarly, in the process of validating soil moisture retrieved from remote sensing, it is challenging to acquire the required pixel-scale soil moisture data. Hydrogen atoms in the cosmic ray source region are not only present in soil moisture but also exist in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. The presence of these hydrogen atom sources inevitably affects the propagation of fast neutrons. Zreda et al. pointed out that the presence of lattice water reduces the detection depth of cosmic rays; however, under the assumption that lattice water and soil organic matter remain constant, these effects can be eliminated through a one-time field soil moisture calibration in the source area. In sparsely vegetated areas, the influence of vegetation can also be eliminated based on field soil moisture calibration, but under rapidly growing vegetation, the moisture content of the vegetation has a certain impact on observations, and there is currently no comprehensive method to correct for this. The presence of water vapor affects the measurement source area of cosmic rays, and MCNPX simulations indicate that the detection radius under saturated water vapor is about 10% lower than that under dry air.
methods: The dataset used in this article comes from the 2012 "Heihe River Basin Eco-Hydrological Comprehensive Remote Sensing Observation Experiment," which mainly includes cosmic ray soil moisture datasets, wireless sensor network datasets (Soil-NET part), and rainfall datasets (Daman Station). During soil moisture observation, only a fast neutron probe needs to be installed; at the beginning of this experiment, only one fast neutron probe was installed for soil moisture observation. This article utilizes cosmic ray instruments to conduct long-term continuous monitoring of soil moisture in the farmland of the Zhangye area in the middle reaches of the Heihe River and compares it with soil moisture wireless sensor data (Wireless Sensor Network, WSN) to study the reliability of the cosmic ray observation results.
dataset: The cosmic ray soil moisture dataset mainly includes raw fast neutron data, raw atmospheric pressure data, etc., with a sampling frequency of 1 hour. Fast neutron data can be used to infer soil moisture information in the study area. SoilNET mainly contains observation data from 50 SoilNET soil moisture/temperature nodes located within the MODIS pixel of the Daman Super Station. Each node can connect to 4 SISOMOP (Simple Soil Moisture Probe) soil moisture/temperature probes, which measure soil moisture and temperature at depths of 4, 10, 20, and 40 cm, with 19 of them distributed within the cosmic ray source area. The sampling frequency of SoilNET nodes is 10 minutes. This paper primarily uses SoilNET node soil moisture data to validate cosmic ray observation results, requiring the aggregation of the original 10-minute data into 1-hour data for synchronization with cosmic ray data. The rainfall dataset (Daman Super Station) mainly includes raw rainfall data, with a sampling frequency of 10 minutes. During use, the original data needs to be aggregated into 1-hour data to analyze the relationship between cosmic ray soil moisture changes and rainfall.
findings: The cosmic ray soil moisture observation system can effectively obtain regional soil moisture content, not only accurately capturing long-term time series soil moisture at the farmland scale but also providing genuinely meaningful surface validation data for remote sensing inversion of soil moisture. By comparison, it can be concluded that cosmic rays reflect a surface-level change in soil moisture, which can well reflect the trend of soil moisture changes beneath the farmland surface. After excluding irrigation period data, the correlation coefficient significantly increased to 0.86, and the RMSE decreased to 0.028 m³/m³.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when using cosmic ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement and how is it addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in using cosmic ray neutron sensing is the influence of hydrogen atoms not only in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. These factors can affect neutron propagation. The presence of lattice water can reduce detection depth, but this can be corrected through a one-time field soil moisture calibration assuming constant lattice water and soil organic matter.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that integrates multiple measurement approaches to study energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert systems?
Example.Answer: A dataset from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin includes long-term energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary data such as hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These data were collected using an eddy covariance system, scintillometer, and automatic weather stations, which measure various parameters with high temporal resolution.

Definition.Question: How is data quality controlled in the collection of soil moisture measurements using cosmic-ray neutron sensors?
Definition.Answer: Data quality control in soil moisture measurement using cosmic-ray neutron sensors includes several steps: data screening to remove erroneous data based on specific criteria (e.g., voltage, humidity, sampling interval, and neutron count changes); pressure correction of neutron counts using a pressure correction formula; and calibration against soil moisture data obtained from field samples or wireless sensor networks.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for measuring soil moisture?
Definition.Answer: Challenges with using cosmic-ray neutron sensors include the influence of hydrogen atoms not only in soil moisture but also in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect neutron propagation. These factors can complicate measurements, requiring correction through field calibration. Additionally, the presence of vegetation and water vapor can alter the measurement radius and depth, necessitating further methodological adjustments.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement compare to traditional soil moisture measurement techniques in terms of spatial coverage and invasiveness?
Comparison.Answer: The cosmic-ray neutron method is a passive, non-invasive measurement technique with a measurement radius of approximately 300 meters, bridging the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing. Traditional methods, such as gravimetric and neutron probe methods, are invasive and typically provide point measurements, lacking the spatial coverage provided by cosmic-ray neutron probes.

Comparison.Question: What challenges are addressed by using cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement compared to remote sensing techniques, and how do these methods complement each other?
Comparison.Answer: Cosmic-ray neutron probes address the challenge of obtaining continuous soil moisture data at a regional scale, which remote sensing methods often miss due to their large pixel size and inability to provide continuous temporal data. Remote sensing provides broad spatial coverage but is limited to specific time intervals, thus cosmic-ray neutron probes complement remote sensing by offering ground-truth validation and filling temporal gaps.

Interpretation.Question: How does the use of cosmic ray neutron sensing contribute to the understanding of soil moisture variations compared to traditional point measurement methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Cosmic ray neutron sensing provides a non-invasive and medium-scale measurement of soil moisture, capturing data from a radius of approximately 300 meters and a depth of 12 to 76 cm. This method bridges the gap between traditional point measurements, which are invasive and limited in spatial representation, and large-scale remote sensing, by offering continuous data that reflect regional soil moisture variations effectively.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges are associated with the integration of cosmic ray neutron data and remote sensing data for soil moisture monitoring?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges include the difficulty in obtaining pixel-scale soil moisture data needed for remote sensing validation, as cosmic ray neutron data capture regional moisture levels influenced by hydrogen atoms in various forms like soil water, organic matter, and vegetation. The presence of these hydrogen sources can affect neutron propagation, and correcting for vegetation water content, especially in rapidly growing vegetation, remains difficult.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological steps are critical in the data processing of cosmic ray neutron observations to ensure accurate soil moisture estimation?
Interpretation.Answer: Critical steps include data filtering based on criteria like voltage levels, relative humidity, and sampling intervals to remove noise. Pressure correction is applied to raw neutron data, and soil moisture calculations require calibration of the N0 parameter, which represents neutron counts under dry soil conditions, using empirical soil moisture data or dense wireless sensor networks. These processing steps ensure the reliability and accuracy of the soil moisture estimates derived from cosmic ray neutron observations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the discrepancy between traditional point measurement methods and remote sensing in capturing regional soil moisture data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Traditional point measurement methods often have a small spatial scale and poor spatial representation, making it difficult to obtain regional soil moisture distribution. Remote sensing can cover large areas quickly, but it provides pixel-scale averages that may not capture continuous data, limiting its application in actual soil moisture monitoring. The cosmic-ray neutron method addresses this gap by offering a medium-scale measurement with a larger measurement radius and depth, providing more representative soil moisture data.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron methods for measuring soil moisture in areas with rapid vegetation growth?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In areas with rapid vegetation growth, the presence of hydrogen atoms in vegetation can impact the propagation of fast neutrons, affecting the measurement of soil moisture. While the influence of stable factors like lattice water and soil organic matter can be corrected through local soil moisture calibration, the varying water content in rapidly growing vegetation poses a challenge, as there is currently no perfect method for adjusting these measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of utilizing cosmic-ray neutron data for soil moisture observation compared to traditional methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing cosmic-ray neutron data for soil moisture observation can effectively fill the gap between traditional point measurements and large-scale remote sensing methods. It allows for non-invasive, medium-scale measurements of soil moisture over a radius of approximately 300 m, providing a more comprehensive understanding of soil moisture distribution in the region. This approach also offers continuous data, which is beneficial for validating remote sensing-derived soil moisture estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the presence of hydrogen atoms in various sources within the observation area impact the outcomes of using cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The presence of hydrogen atoms in sources other than soil moisture, such as lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, can influence the propagation of fast neutrons and thus affect the measurement outcomes. These factors may lead to reduced detection depth of cosmic-ray neutrons, though their impact can be mitigated by field calibration of soil moisture. However, rapidly growing vegetation can still pose challenges that are not yet fully addressed.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of ensuring long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Ensuring long-term observational datasets for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and supporting sustainable development. Such datasets enable a quantitative understanding of oasis–desert interactions and are significant for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals. They also provide essential insights for protecting the ecological and socioeconomic well-being of oases.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of utilizing cosmic ray neutron sensors for measuring soil moisture in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to obtain regional soil moisture content effectively over a substantial area, bridging the gap between point-based measurements and large-scale remote sensing observations, and to provide surface validation data for remote sensing soil moisture retrievals.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange studies?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining this balance is crucial for sustainable oasis development, achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, and supporting the ecological security and socioeconomic development of oases, which play a significant role in stabilizing ecological environments and agricultural productivity.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of comparing cosmic ray neutron data with soil moisture wireless sensor network data in agricultural settings?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goals include assessing the reliability of cosmic ray neutron observations, validating their ability to accurately capture long-term soil moisture trends at the farmland scale, and comparing these findings with wireless sensor network data to enhance understanding and verification of soil moisture dynamics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the detailed procedures for correcting atmospheric pressure in a cosmic ray neutron soil moisture observation system, and how does this affect the reliability of the data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The detailed procedure for correcting atmospheric pressure involves using a pressure correction formula provided in the instrument's manual to adjust the raw fast neutron counts to account for variations in air pressure. This correction, resulting in the corrected fast neutron count (N1C_cor), enhances the reliability of soil moisture data by ensuring that variations in atmospheric pressure do not skew the neutron count data, which is directly related to soil moisture content.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can the cosmic ray neutron method be effectively calibrated for accurate soil moisture measurement in regions with sparse vegetation or varying soil organic content?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Calibration of the cosmic ray neutron method for soil moisture involves determining the dry soil fast neutron count (N0) using either measured soil samples from the area or through dense soil moisture sensor networks. Adjustments for hydrogen content from other sources such as soil organic matter and vegetation are made, often by conducting on-site soil moisture corrections that factor in these variables to ensure that the neutron count accurately reflects soil moisture levels.

Enablement.Question: What instrumentation and data processing methods enable the accurate collection of soil moisture data using cosmic-ray neutron sensors in agricultural areas?
Enablement.Answer: The data collection method involves using a cosmic-ray neutron sensor placed 0.5m above the ground with a sampling frequency of 1 hour. Data processing includes screening based on voltage levels, relative humidity, sampling intervals, and neutron count variability, followed by pressure correction and instrument calibration to accurately reflect soil moisture content.

Enablement.Question: How do the integration of wireless sensor networks and cosmic-ray neutron sensors enable comprehensive soil moisture monitoring in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The integration involves using wireless sensor networks (WSN) to provide soil moisture data at various depths (4, 10, 20, and 40 cm) which complements the cosmic-ray neutron sensors that measure the soil moisture over a larger area with a radius of approximately 300m. This combination allows for detailed temporal and spatial soil moisture monitoring.

Enablement.Question: What are the challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron sensors for soil moisture measurement, and how can they be mitigated to enhance data accuracy?
Enablement.Answer: Challenges include the influence of hydrogen atoms from various sources like crystal water and vegetation on neutron propagation. To mitigate these effects, calibration using local soil moisture samples is necessary, and adjustments for vegetation and water vapor are made using empirical or simulation-based methods.

Expectation.Question: Why might traditional point measurement methods be insufficient for capturing soil moisture distribution on a regional scale?
Expectation.Answer: Traditional point measurement methods are insufficient for capturing soil moisture distribution on a regional scale because they are often intrusive, have small measurement scales, and lack spatial representativeness, making it difficult to gather comprehensive regional data. These methods cannot bridge the gap between point measurements and large-scale remote sensing observations, which is crucial for acquiring accurate soil moisture information over farmlands or small watershed scales.

Expectation.Question: What are the potential challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement, and how might these affect data accuracy?
Expectation.Answer: The potential challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron sensing for soil moisture measurement include interference from hydrogen atoms not solely found in soil moisture, such as those in lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor. These can affect the propagation of fast neutrons and hence the accuracy of measurements. Additionally, changes in vegetation water content can impact observations, especially under rapidly growing vegetation, and there's currently no complete correction method for this issue.

Judgmental.Question: What is your perspective on the potential for expanding current datasets to improve the monitoring of soil moisture and other environmental parameters in arid regions, using recent technological advances?
Judgmental.Answer: There is considerable potential for expanding current datasets to enhance monitoring in arid regions. Recent technological advances, such as the development of wireless sensor networks and improvements in remote sensing, offer opportunities to complement cosmic ray neutron sensing data. These technologies can provide finer spatial resolution and more continuous data acquisition, bridging the gap between traditional methods and remote sensing. Additionally, integrating these diverse data sources can improve the accuracy and reliability of monitoring regional soil moisture and other environmental parameters, supporting ecological stability and sustainable development efforts.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets are compiled to analyze carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Assertion.Answer: Datasets for carbon exchange analysis in oasis-desert ecosystems are compiled from long-term observational data collected by systems like eddy covariance and scintillometers. These datasets include fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and additional auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, which support comprehensive analysis of ecosystem interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in using cosmic-ray neutron probes for soil moisture measurement and propose potential solutions for improving data accuracy in agricultural fields.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in using cosmic-ray neutron probes include the presence of hydrogen atoms in sources other than soil moisture, such as lattice water, soil organic matter, vegetation, and water vapor, which can affect neutron propagation. Zreda et al. highlighted that lattice water might reduce detection depth, but these effects can be minimized by calibrating with soil moisture measurements from the area. In sparse vegetation areas, adjustments can be made, but rapidly growing vegetation poses difficulties. Water vapor presence can alter the detection radius, with simulations indicating a 10% reduction under saturated vapor conditions compared to dry air. Addressing these challenges requires calibration techniques and potentially combining data from multiple sensor types to improve accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods utilized for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis-desert ecosystems and how these methods are integrated to form a comprehensive dataset.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods in oasis-desert ecosystems involve a combination of observational datasets from both artificial and natural systems. These datasets include long-term measurements of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes, along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data are collected using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, while hydrometeorological data are recorded by automatic weather stations with a 10-minute average period. Groundwater table data are also included. These methods are integrated by collecting, processing, and archiving data to build a comprehensive dataset that captures the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems.
